message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The delayed menstrual period and lower abdominal pain suggest ectopic pregnancy, where the fertilized ovum implants outside of the uterus. Endometrial biopsy showed decidualization of the endometrium without chorionic villi, which supports the diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy. None of the other options are consistent with these findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of decidualization of the endometrium without chorionic villi suggests an ectopic pregnancy, which is the fertilized ovum outside the uterus. Option A refers to leiomyoma, option C refers to plasma cell endometritis, and option D refers to a complete mole, all of which are not supported by the biopsy findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest ectopic pregnancy, which occurs when a fertilized ovum implants outside of the uterus. Endometrial biopsy showing decidualization without chorionic villi also supports this diagnosis. None of the other options are consistent with the clinical presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and biopsy results suggest an ectopic pregnancy, specifically a tubal pregnancy. This is confirmed with further testing, such as transvaginal ultrasound or measurement of beta-hCG levels. The other options, such as benign proliferation of myometrial smooth muscle, endometrial infiltration by plasma cells, or an empty ovum fertilized by two sperm, do not fit with the patient’s presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of decidualization without chorionic villi suggests a fertilized ovum outside the uterus – specifically, an ectopic pregnancy. The other options are not consistent with the patient’s symptoms and findings on endometrial biopsy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a delayed menstrual period, lower abdominal pain, and a soft, mildly enlarged uterus. These findings suggest ectopic pregnancy, which is a fertilized ovum outside the uterus. The other options are not likely based on the given information.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a delayed menstrual period and lower abdominal pain, suggesting an ectopic pregnancy, which is confirmed by the endometrial biopsy showing decidualization but no chorionic villi. Option B is the only one that suggests a fertilized ovum outside the uterus, which is characteristic of an ectopic pregnancy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and signs suggest ectopic pregnancy. The presence of decidualization of the endometrium without chorionic villi support this diagnosis. Other options are unlikely given the clinical presentation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a delayed menstrual period and endometrial biopsy shows decidualization of the endometrium without chorionic villi, which suggests a pregnancy outside the uterus (ectopic pregnancy). A fertilized ovum outside the uterus is the most likely finding among the options. The other options do not fit with the clinical presentation and biopsy results.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and biopsy results suggest an ectopic pregnancy, which is a fertilized ovum outside the uterus. Options A, C, and D are not consistent with the patient’s presentation.
